prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: z=0.7011 838956 CO43
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mapping of the CO(4-3) molecular gas in COSMOS 838956 in the most extended configuration available in band 6 (C34-6), for a resolution of 0.16".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The CO(4-3) and CO(5-4) lines will be observable in bands 6 and 7 at respectively 271.025 and 338.762 GHz for COSMOS 838956, and 271.488 and 339.340 GHz for COSMOS 822872. We estimated the expected CO fluxes from our IRAM PHIBSS2 measurements, which respectively yield for COSMOS 838956 and COSMOS 822872 CO(2-1) peak intensities of 3.3 and 3.7 mJy, and velocity-integrated fluxes of 363 and 1036 mJy km s-1. We conservatively take CO(4-3)/CO(2-1) and CO(5-4)/CO(2-1) line ratios of 3 and 4.5 - i.e., below the maximum values of 4 and 6.25 we would have if the CO line SED was to follow the Rayleigh- Jeans law -, and estimate the CO(4-3) and CO(5-4) fluxes. To estimate the expected flux per substructure on the CO(4-3) map, we assume that the total velocity integrated fluxes SCODv are equally distributed among N = 10 substructures of about 1 kpc size spanning dv = 30 km s-1 each. Equaling SCODv = N speak dv, we derive speak, the expected line intensity for the substructures on the CO(4-3) map. We find 3.6 mJy for COSMOS 838956 and 10.4 mJy for COSMOS 822872, and choose the sensitivity to have signal-to-noise ratios (SNR) of at least 6. For the CO(5-4) detection, we evaluate the expected peak fluxes at 14.8 mJy for COSMOS 838956 and 16.6 mJy for COSMOS 822872. As the CO(5-4)/CO(2-1) line ratio may drop and be below the 4.5 value we assumed, we require a high SNR of about 13 and choose the sensitivity accordingly. We further use a line-to-continuum ratio of 30 (Combes et al. 1999) to estimate the expected continuum at about 0.5 mJy. This is consistent with the dust temperature estimate based on redshift, stellar mass, and SFR of Magnelli et al. (2013), adopting mean Herschel-based SEDs. As the continuum will be smoothed in frequency at about 8 GHz, we expect to reach the same detection level for the continuum and for the lines with a spectral resolution of 15 km s-1: in each 0.16" beam where we detect CO(4-3) at SNR>6, we also expect to detect the continuum at SNR>5.
Since it is possible to do it without compromising our science goals, we designed the correlator configuration to place the 13CO(4-3) line in band 6 to maximize serendipity.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: z=0.7011 838956 C054
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detection of the CO(5-4) line in COSMOS 838956 with a 1" resolution in band 7 (configuration C34-1).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The CO(4-3) and CO(5-4) lines will be observable in bands 6 and 7 at respectively 271.025 and 338.762 GHz for COSMOS 838956, and 271.488 and 339.340 GHz for COSMOS 822872. prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: z=0.6982 822872 CO54

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose a high-resolution CO and continuum imaging program of two z=0.7 massive star-forming galaxies to investigate in detail the star formation processes, the morphology and the kinematics of galaxies after the peak epoch of star formation. Our sample consists of a main-sequence isolated disk and of an interacting galaxy. Combining the data with our PHIBSS2 and HST imaging, we will derive their spatially-resolved distribution of stars, star formation, molecular gas, optical extinction, their gas kinematics, and the CO excitation. This will enable us to investigate the star formation processes on subgalactic scales at intermediate redshift, notably through a spatially-resolved Kennicutt-Schmidt relation, and to characterize the velocity and velocity dispersion fields of the molecular gas. This pilot study is complementary to the IRAM PHIBSS and PHIBSS2 programs, which investigate early galaxy evolution and star formation from a larger statistical sample of about 200 sources but with lower resolution. ALMA resolution will permit to reach the scales of the star-forming regions, which is crucial to our understanding of the transitional period of the winding-down of star formation.
